questions.question_text: An instructor separates the class into groups. The learners are not working as hard in the groups as they would if they were working individually. Which of the following could the instructor do to create more group interaction? (Select TWO).

discussion.content:
To create more group interaction when learners are not working as hard in groups as they would individually, the instructor could do the following:

A. Create groups with members from different backgrounds. This can increase the diversity of ideas and perspectives within the group and promote more discussion and collaboration.

E. Clearly define the role for each of the group members. This can help ensure that everyone knows what is expected of them and can contribute to the group's success. Clear roles and responsibilities can also help prevent free-riding and increase accountability.

Emphasizing conformity (B) or limiting individual accountability (D) is not likely to increase group interaction or engagement, as it can lead to groupthink and a lack of motivation. Additionally, tying group participation to individual rewards (C) can create competition and undermine the collaborative spirit of the group.

questions.question_text: A learner asks the instructor a question that was covered before the lunch break. Which of the following would the BEST response be from the instructor?

discussion.content: The BEST response from the instructor when a learner asks a question that was covered before the lunch break is to answer the question in short form, citing where it was covered previously (Option A). This approach acknowledges the learner's question and provides a brief answer while also reminding the learner where the information was previously covered. This can help reinforce the material for the learner and encourage them to pay closer attention in future sessions. Redirecting the question to the class (Option B) may not be helpful if other learners do not remember or understand the material, and it can also make the learner who asked the question feel unsupported. Providing a more in-depth answer (Option C) can be time-consuming and may not be necessary if the information was already covered. Asking the learner to remain after class (Option D) can be helpful for individualized support, but it may not be necessary if the question can be answered quickly in class.

questions.question_text:
A presentation heavy with procedural details was just completed. The subsequent demonstration exercise is not flowing well. Which of the following will be the
MOST productive assistance the instructor can provide?

discussion.content:
C. Ask probing questions to trigger the learner's memory of the procedure.

If the demonstration exercise is not flowing well, it is likely that the learners are having difficulty recalling the procedural details presented in the previous presentation. Asking probing questions can help the learners remember the procedure and apply it to the exercise. This can also help the instructor identify areas where the learners may need additional explanation or clarification. Reviewing the presentation in more detail or quickly leading the learners in a question and answer session may not be as effective, as the learners may not be able to retain the information or apply it to the exercise. Handing out copies of the procedure from the slide presentation may also not be as effective, as it may not help the learners apply the procedure to the exercise.

questions.question_text: During a tedious technical exercise the instructor notes that the learners are nervous and apprehensive about starting. Which of the following should the instructor do?

discussion.content:
The BEST action the instructor can take when learners are nervous and apprehensive about starting a technical exercise is to reassure everyone that they will perform well and monitor their progress on a more personal basis. This will help to reduce anxiety and give learners a sense of support and guidance. Option A is the correct answer.

Option B is not the best solution because providing extra time may not address the root cause of the learners' anxiety, and it may not be feasible in all situations.

Option C is not the best solution because repeating the lecture portion may not necessarily address the learners' anxiety about the exercise, and it may not be an efficient use of time.

Option D is not the best solution because telling a humorous story may not be appropriate for all learners or situations, and it may not effectively address the learners' anxiety.

choices.B: Give the learners extra time to complete the exercise.
choices.C: Present the lecture portion again to reinforce the exercise and then follow up with a question and answer session.
choices.A: Reassure everyone that they will perform well and monitor their progress on a more personal basis.
choices.D: Tell a humorous story to make the learners feel more comfortable during the exercise.

questions.question_text: An instructor has been assigned to work with a learner in a one-to-one setting to improve the learner's understanding of a particular subject. When they meet, the learner seems uninterested and unmotivated by the subject. Which of the following would be the BEST way for the instructor to motivate the learner?

choices.B: The instructor should remind the learner of the benefits of one-to-one instruction and that they need to apply themselves more during the instruction periods.
choices.D: The instructor should strive to find out what interests the learner and incorporate these things into each instruction period.
choices.C: The instructor should assign additional research to the learner; this will increase the learner's familiarity and interest in the subject.
choices.A: The instructor should include more handouts, charts and graphs in the instruction period; this will keep the learner on task.

discussion.content:
The answer should be ---
D. The instructor should strive to find out what interests the learner and incorporate these things into each instruction period.

The best way for the instructor to motivate the learner would be option D, which is to strive to find out what interests the learner and incorporate these things into each instruction period. This approach would allow the instructor to tailor the instruction to the learner's interests and make the subject more relevant and engaging for the learner. By understanding the learner's interests, the instructor can also show the learner how the subject relates to their interests and how it can be useful in their daily lives. This approach is more likely to increase the learner's motivation and engagement than simply providing more handouts, reminding them of the benefits of one-to-one instruction, or assigning additional research.

This should be D - The instructor should strive to find out what interests the learner and incorporate these things into each instruction period.

Making the sessions more relevant to the learned does the trick.
